characters: MISS TAMMY AND THE EMPTY COFFIN
A PACK OF OREOS, A QUART OF SCOTCH AND THOU

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: How has he been, Janet?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: He's doing all right, I think. He should get out more often. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il.

dialogues.speaker: JANET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When he doesn't have anything to do he just sits all day. I've seen him spend an hour making the bed.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: That's not too unusual. He has to make the transition at his own speed. (a beat) How much longer will you be living here? Janet is a handsome but somewhat bland woman. Ali her instincts are kind and generous but right now she's trying to juggle two lives simultaneously.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: As long as he needs me. A couple more weeks, a month if necessary. I just can't let him handle this ail alone.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: How do Charlie and Cliff get along?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Quite well, actually. Cliff thinks Charlie's quite a hero.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: He is. (a beat) When will you and Cliff be getting married?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Sometime in the fall. I'm not sure yet. There's no need to rush.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: We'll have to have a long talk about this in a couple days. There'll have to be some sort of statement to the press. Everybody's interested in Charlie. (excusing himself) I've got to run. I'll just say goodbye to Charlie. Maxwell gives Janet a polite kiss and walks out back,  12. Maxwell walks across EXT. BACKYARD toward the barn where Charlie is standing. Rane is poking around in the dirt with his foot. He turns as he hears Maxwell walking toward him:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Hey, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: I've got to keep moving, Rane. Don't forget the billboard thing in the morning and we have a meeting after that.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (touches his chest) You still having the pain here?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Comes and goes. I see the Doc regular. Maxwell nods. Mark, dressed in sneakers, jeans and a sweatshirt, walks toward them with a football.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (to Mark) Gonna throw some football, Mark?

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: It ain't even football season.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: You don't have to have seasons for everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I'd rather be a surfer.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (stepping back) Throw it here, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (excusing self) See you later. Mark hurls the football awkwardly at his father. Mark isn't much of a Quarterback and the ball wobbles in Rane's general direction -- but then Charlie isn't much of an End either, and he stabs at the football like a man catching flies.  13. After Maxwell exits, Rane, holding the football, stands and looks at his son, not quite knowing what to do next. cur To:  14.

dialogues.speaker: A GUEST FOR DINNER
dialogues.text: SUPPERTIME, that same day. Janet, Charlie, Mark and Cliff sit around the small kitchen table. Cliff, Janet's future husband, is wearing his policeman's uniform. He is about thirty and handsome in an average sort of way. His sharply starched blue uniform gives him a sexiness he would not normally have. They pass around bowls of mashed potatoes, peas and roast beef. For the moment each seems more interested in eating than talking. On the wall behind Rane is a grease-spattered map of Viet Nam with certain strategic locations circled with a red Magic Marker. Finally Charlie breaks the silence:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: How is that new team they have in Houston, the Astros?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: (looking up) I went to one of their games last year. ~

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: They ain't much good. Baseball's dumb, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: (to Mark) At least they're better than those Wahoos up in Dallas, the Texas Rangers. Washington D.C.'s rejects. Mark giggles: there is an obvious rapport between he and Cliff.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Corpus ain't part of Texas anyway. Janet is referring to a private joke between Cliff and Mark, who respond with short chuckles. They don't mean to cut Charlie out of their little jokes Â«= they just don't know how to get him in.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: If they try to give us some of their loser teams, we should succede from the state,  15.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Nothing succeeds like succession. They all giggle again. There's a guest for dinner all right, but it isn't clirr ~~ it's Charlie. It's as if he inadvertently walked in on somebody else's family.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: They didn't even have that Astro team when I was here before,

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Texas was the better for it, too. Mark giggles again (everything Cliff says is funny to him) and there is another awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (looking around) I think I'll have a drink. You want a drink, Cliff?

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: (eating) Ne, not yet, Charlie. Charlie reaches over to a nearby cabinet and pulls out a quart of J&B. Janet looks on disapprovingly as he pours himself several fingers. Taking a healthy swig, he feels the ripples of relaxation move through his body.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I kinda like to see them Astros Play, you know? cur TO:  16.

dialogues.speaker: MISS TAMMY AND THE EMPTY COFFIN
dialogues.text: A large billboard somewhere in Corpus Christi reads:

dialogues.speaker: RELEASE LT. COL. CHARLES RANE
dialogues.text: Surrounded by local dignitaries and photographers, Charle Rane, axe in hand, stands at the base of the billboard. He poses awkwardly for the photographers before chopping down the last leg of the billboard. A cluster of aging Veterans, their uniforms dripping with decorations, beam with particular pride. The billboard falls and a CHEER goes up from the crowd. cuT To: INT. COL. MAXWELL'S OFFICE. Charles Rane sits in a large padded chair talking with Col. Maxwell. It is a psychiatrist-patient relationship, a relationship somewhat complicated by the fact, however, that they are both wearing their uniforms. Rane rambles on, speaking as if to no one but himself:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You know, Bill, it took me three days just to figure out how to tie my damn shoes. I feel like such an ass.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Seven years is a long time. I'd be happy if I knew which shoe went where.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Ah, comeon, Bill. Don't be so obvious.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be obvious, Rane. So you can see it. Because in the end only you can help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: So what else is going to help me? Carting me around and praising me for a bunch of crap I never did? I don't know if anything can help.  17.

dialogues.speaker: RANE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sometimes I can't sleep at night and get up and feel I just gotta tear something. Like the Naval Air Base -- wouldn't that be something for your headlines, Bill? (pause) They owe me something, you know, something more than money.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You know.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: A lot of people think the war was immoral. Do you think that, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (irritated) Of course not. But their money don't solve everything either. Sometimes I think they sent back an empty body and I wasn't in it. Just another coffin. I'm sick of being a hero, I'm sick of being all locked in.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Maybe it's sex. Maybe sex is the way out.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You said that before. No, it ain't sex. Everything's sex with you guys, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Has the sex changed?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: How is it?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: The same.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: That's not too unusual. Sometimes this can go on for six months or more.  18.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Had a sex dream last night, though. First in years. Figur'd you'd like to hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: What was it about?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: For a while I had dreams about food and medicine, like before, then I stopped and I was afraid I was going to have dreams about the torture and all. But last night I had a dream and I was screwing Tammy Wynette on a stairs. She was leaning back against the stairs, wearing this sort of fluffy yellow dress without underpants. I was wearing my uniform with my pants half-way down. Miss Tammy sort of had her dress hoisted above her waist. She had her hair stacked up in a sort of curly-cue fashion and kept going, "Oh, 1 WAH (an embarrassed smile) Does that mean anything, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: How did you know it was Miss Tammy?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I came though, Charlie. Now that means something, don't 1t? (a beat) I was always afraid I'd dream I wouldn't. It was like Nam. Ita dream I was going into combat and I'd get there and it was all over. That's what it was like, going to Nam and not getting into combat. It was like getting in bed with a beautiful woman and not being able to come.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: How did you know it was Miss Tammy?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I just sorta knew. I kept thinking, "Wow, this 1s gotta be Miss Tammy Wynette." She didn't even sing.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Do you like her singing?  19.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. She's my favoritist singer. I used to keep thinking about that. That Tammy or Loretta Lynn would have a new song out somewhere and I was too far away to hear it. I love that song, "Apartment Number 9."

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Did you tell Janet about the dream?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: She wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: She's a woman, you know? cur TO:  20.

dialogues.speaker: PILLOW TALK
dialogues.text: THAT NIGHT. Rane stands in MARK'S BEDROOM watching his Son sleep. On the wall above Mark's bed hangs a large poster of Mick Jagger prancing a devil's Jig at Altamont. Charlie closes the door softly, then exits. Rane walks into the MASTER BEDROOM, Janet, wearing a sheer nightgown, sits up in bed reading Coronet, Charlie strips down to his shorts and gets into bed next to Janet. The POW "Dictionary of Slang" rests on the bedstand. Putting down her magazine, Janet snuggles up to Charlie. Her nipples can be seen through the sheer blue fabric of her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: How was Dr. Maxwell today?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Fine, I guess. She embraces him:

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: You know, I thought I'd never have you back in bed again.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I never thought I'd be back,

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: You'll be all right, won't you, darling?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I'll be all right.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It's too bad it couldn't be different,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: It's all right, baby, honest. I understand,

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I know. Life can be so hard sometimes. She runs her hand up and down his leg underneath the covers.  2l.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: (sexily) You wanna try it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (hesitant ) Well, I don't know...it's just...

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I understand, baby.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Dr. Maxwell says I shouldn't rush it.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I'm glad you were able to, ah, get along while I was gone. I mean really. It's important. A person has to live his own life,

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: I understand, darling.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I mean, is it-good with. Cliff?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It's good.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Real good?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: It's good enough.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I'm glad. That's the way it should be, Janet renews her pseudo-sexual stimulation.

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: But what about you. Charlie. It should be good for you, too.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: If you can live with it, I can live without it. (weak smile) Janet's eyes fill up with pathos and sympathy:  226

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: Oh, Charlie, Charlie. She embraces him, TIMECUT TO: LATER THAT NIGHT. The room is dark, Char- lie, unable to sleep, gets out of bed and begins dressing CUT TO EXT. DRIVE-IN THEATER, Rane's big red Caddy (top up) pulls into an outdoor theater. The marquee advertises: "DEEP THROAT--ADULTS ONLY." cUT TO: Rane sits behind the wheel watching the film. The light from the screen is reflected on his face. MOANS and GROANS are heard OFF SCREEN. He takes another hit from his quart of J&B. Turning to his left, Rane looks into the cars parked nearby. He sees DARK FORMS engaged in various stages of necking and petting. Feeling someone staring at him, he turns and looks to his left: there, two cars away, sits a YOUNG MAN hunched in the front seat with a beer can in his hand. The young punk's face is gaunt and drained of color. He wears a green plaid western shirt and Army jacket. Those who have read another script of mine titled Taxi-Driver will recognize this young man. His name ts Travis Bickle, Travis and Rane stare at each other for a moment: two fuses slowly burning down. cur TO:  236

dialogues.speaker: CLOTHES MAKE THE MAN
dialogues.text: Charles Rane drives into Corpus Christi the next morning in his long red Cadillac (top down). He is wearing a red plaid work shirt. He parks the car and walks down the sidewalk toward BRANNIGAN'S, a fashionable men's clothing store, INSIDE, Rane is greeted by BRANNIGAN, the owner. Bran- nigan and his help are all nattily dressed; Charlie looks out of place in his comfortable flannel shirt and work jeans and shoes.

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: Lt. Colonel Rane! Welcome! We've all been waiting for you. Colonel Maxwell said you would be in sometime this week. (pause) We want you to feel right at home and leave everything to us. Don't worry about a thing. We will fix you up so you look fantastic. Everything's on us, it's our honor to be able to do this. Rane smiles politely and looks uncomfortable from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Well, I appreciate this, you know. I really do. Brannigan gestures for Charlie to follow:

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: Now just follow me. I have just the thing for you. You will look very nice in brown and we have the latest styles. I have just the suit for you. Brannigan leads Rane toward a clothes rack. TIMECUT: Rane, fully dressed in a new suit, shirt and shoes, stands before a tripartite mirror. Brannigan was right: he does look fantastic. He wears a deep brown velvet suit, a Cardin yellow-and-brown flora patterned shirt and brown high-heeled shoes. He is a transformed man: sexy, debonair, fresh out of the pages of Gentlemen's Quarterly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks into the mirror, recognizes that he's sup= posed to look sharp, but, jacked up on those goddamn heels, he just doesn't feel sharp. He starts to hack-cough, but suppresses it,

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: This suit never looked better than it does on you, Lt. Colonel Rane. (a beat) Try it out. Walk around, Rane tests the fit of his new suit. Unsteady on his two~ inch heels, Charlie walks with an uncertain gail.

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: (uncertain) Do you like it? How does it fit? Rane attempts to put Brannigan at ease:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Oh, it fits fine. Real nice. I like it very much. (a beat) And comfortable, too.

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: I'm so glad you like it. (a beat; hesitant) Ah, Lt. Colonel Rane, would you mind if we took a picture of you in your new suit? To hang in our window, We're very proud to have you as our customer, Brannigan gestures to the rear of the store and a young man walks out with a camera and flash attachment,

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: Now, Lt. Colonel, if you'll just sort of stand here in the middle of the room, (gestures) Rane walks to the center of the store, feeling more like a naked man in a bus terminal than a hero.

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: There, that's fine. , (to photographer) All right, Bob, you stand over there,  256 Rane poses. âThe photographer readies his camera.

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: You don't happen to have any medals with you, do you, Lt. Colonel? It would look sort of nice if we could pin a medal or two on the front of the suit. A real touch of class.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (apologetic) No, I don't, I left them all at home.

dialogues.speaker: BRANNIGAN
dialogues.text: All right then, we'll shoot it like this. There is a CLICK and a bulb flashes in Charlie's face. TIMECUT: Rane steps out of the store and walks down the sidewalk toward his Cadillac, Wearing his new suit, he carries a box of his old clothes under one arm. He glances at his reflection in the store windows as he passes. He is not pleased with what he sees. He is still trying to get the knack of walking on high heels Suddenly fed up with what he sees, he stops and stares at himself in a store window. He tucks the box under his left arm, and, walking toward the car, pulls his floral shirt right off his chest with his right hand. At first the shirt doesn't come, He yanks and tugs and rips it off in shreds. Walking more quickly toward his car, Rane reaches down and removes his shoes one by one, tossing each one a aifferent direction as he goes. He wears yellow-and- brown argyle socks. He throws the box into the open back seat of the con= vertible, hops in, starts the engine and squeals off. cuT To:  26.

dialogues.speaker: WELCOME HERO
dialogues.text: Rane brakes his Caddy into the dusty shoulder in front of his house. He gets out of the car and walks toward the house in his argyle stocking feet. Under his brown velvet suitcoat are the shredded remnants of a Cardin shirt, and, under that, a sleeveless undershirt. He notices a brown Ford station wagon (the kind with fake wood on the side) in the driveway as he walks past, but pays it no mind. Three of the license plate numbers are "RFD," Rane opens the door and walks into the house, As Rane steps into the LIVING ROOM he feels the presence of someone behind him, The steel blue barrel of a .38 revolver is raised to the back of his head. A raspy Mexican voice says firmly:

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN VOICE
dialogues.text: Welcome home, hero. Sit down. Rane walks slowly across the room and sits on the sofa underneath the Memory Wall. To his right is the new color TV; some of the presents atop it have been opened. Among the presents we notice some cologne and -~ of all things -- Barry Sadler's 1969 "Green Berets" album, Rane surveys the room: A fortyish MEXICAN in a Robert Hall suit stands before him with a .38 in his hand. Two young Texas thugs stand against the far wall. They wear cowboy boots, faded jeans, western shirts, Stetsons and shit-eating grins. They also carry revolvers. The door to Mark's bedroom is ajar, Janet and Mark, frightened, sit on the edge of the bed watching someone out of Rane'ts view,

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: We hear you got some money hid, hero. We'd like to have it. Rane says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: You might as well talk up now, hero, cause you're going to talk sooner or later and I can guarantee sooner is going to be a lot preferable to later.  aT. Rane opens his mouth: words come out. He speaks in an empty monotone:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: That money is all I got to show for seven years. I will never give it up.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: You will give it up gringo. You know that. , CAMERA CLOSES IN on Rane: he says nothing. The Mexican motions to the two thugs, He speaks in a tired professional tone of voice:

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: All right, T-Bird, bust heem, Pegale. T-BIRD, the first Texan, walks over to Rane and clips him across the chin with the barrel of his gun. Blood appears on Charlie's lower cheek, T-Bird aims his re~ volver point blank at Rane's left eye. The SECOND TEXAN, a hulking young man, walks around the other side of Rane and puts a knife to his throat, A arop of blood trickles down his neck,

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Te duele, hero? pauses) Look, I don't want to fool around. I'm as patriotic as the next guy but If you don't tell us where that 124 Gs is hid, you are going to be dead very soon, Janet's SOBS can be heard from the bedroom, CAMREA CLOSES IN on Rane again, and all of a sudden we realize how he survived seven years of torture: It is as if Charles Rane has removed his mind from his body. It doesn't matter what anybody does to his body because he is no longer in it. These men are torturing an empty body. Rane's awkwardness and uneasiness are suddenly gone. His face is blank, calm, distant; he is now in a world he totaliy understands, He is more experienced at being tortured than his torturers are at torturing,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He really doesn't have the choice whether to tell them where the money is hidden or not. He could not tell if he wanted to, He has lost his capacity to give in, As the Mexican's boots step toward Rane, we notice they are made from multi-colored suede patches. The Texans step aside as the Mexican pulls a gold butane lighter from his pocket. Igniting it, the Mexican runs the lighter up and down Charlie's cheek. Even though he is not tied or held down, Rane does not resist.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Come on, hero, comeon. Where de mangos hid, hey? The Mexican pulls his lighter away from Rane's blistered cheek,

dialogues.speaker: T-BIRD
dialogues.text: Man, that usually does it.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND TEXAN
dialogues.text: Sheeit, that old boy is a tough un. (chortles) The Second Texan is obviously a low grade intelligence, The Mexican looks at hima moment. Thinking, the Mexican pulls out a cigarette and lights it with his lighter. Suddenly -- angry and exasperated =~ the Mexican chucks down his cigarette and lighter and grabs Rane by his brown velvet lapels,

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Cabron! I can make this damn exican talk, The Mexican hauls Charlie into the KITCHEN and the Texans follow, Passing in front of the grease=spattered map of Viet Nam, the Mexican grabs Charlie by the left wrist and leads him over to the sink, He turns on the faucet, then flips the switch: we hear the familiar grinding sound. Holding Charlie's hand above the disposal, the Mexican yells:

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Talk now, hero! Rane says nothing.  296 The Mexican thrusts Charliets hand into the disposal. We hear a hideous grinding sound. Rane's face is blitzed with pain.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Cabron, gringo. Me cago en la Teche de tu puta madre. Maricon, Concha. Bizocho. The Mexican pulls Rane's hand out of the disposal and examines it (we do not see the hand).

dialogues.speaker: T-BIRD
dialogues.text: (with admiration) Es un tio barbaro.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: (to Rane) Talk! Rane says nothing. The Mexican rethrusts Charlie's hand into the disposal. This time the Mexican does not remove it so quickly. We here the GRINDING of flesh and bones as we watch Rane's agonized, stoic face. His body cries out for him to break down but he cannot, When the Mexican finally does remove Rane's hand and switch off the disposal, we see (although only fleetingly that the fingers have been ground away. The Mexican walks back toward the living room. T-Bird follows, The Second Texan grabs a kitchen towel and wraps up the bloody mess under Ranets left cuff.

dialogues.speaker: T-BIRD
dialogues.text: I don't think we're going to get it, jefe.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Maybe not. But we got one more chance, As they enter the LIVING ROOM the Mexican calls into Mark's bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Melio. Traigame son esposo. The Second Texan brings Charlie back into the living room and sets him down on the sofa. Rane looks up at the Mexican,  30. MELIO, a young Mexican hood wearing tight green pants, brings Janet in from the bedroom, Janet tries to scream when she sees Charlie but the only thing that comes from her mouth is a pathetic croaking sound. The Mexican gestures and Melio forces Janet to her knees in front of Charlie. Melio puts his small .32 automatic to her temples,

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Mano, in another time and place I would be proud to know you becausÃ© you are... sO Macho, But now I am going to have to kill your wife if you do not tell me where that money is hid right away. Iam telling the truth. You know Your wife is very close to death. CAMERA CLOSES IN on Ranets face: there is no emotion. CAMERA stays on Rane's face as we hear three voice tracks One voice is Janet's, another the Mexi~ can's, and the third -- and dominant -- is Charlie's own simultaneously. narrative VOICE OVER. he has told Maxwell: JANET O,.S. Tell them, Charlie! Oh please, please, please tell them! It's not worth it. Oh, Charlie, tell then. . RANE V.0,. They would walk into my cell, two of them, the one we called O11 Can Harry and Ap Chong, his assistant. They would say âToday is the day you die Lt. Rane" and put a gun to my head and pull the trigger. And the gun would be empty. But you were always afraid because sometimes they did it to prisoners and the gun wouldn't be emptyese It is an excerpt from something a reminiscence from Hanoi, MEXICAN 0.8. Do that, hero. Tell them, You got 15 seconds left, Comeon, talk. Ten seconds. Talk, Five seconds. Talk, hero. All these voices abrupt HALT when we hear the sharp sound of a .32 automatic discharging.

dialogues.speaker: BAAM
dialogues.text: There is an ABBREVIATED SCREAM, a SILENCE, and the THUD of a body slumping to the floor, Rane'ts face is as calm and placid as the distant sea. We hear Mark's SCREAMING VOICE and CAMERA CUTS to him running from the bedroom:  31.

dialogues.speaker: MARK
dialogues.text: I know where the money's hid. I know where. It's in the barn. Out back. Under the tools. I saw him hide it. Even this draws no emotion from Rane,

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: (softly) Menos mai. Show him where, kid. Go on. The Second Texan leads Mark out back. TIMECUT: The Mexican and his assistants look at the money briefly as the Second Texan opens the sack on the chair, Rane sits unmoving, Janet's body at his feet, Mark, in shock, sits nearby. Charlie looks over at his money.

dialogues.speaker: T-BIRD
dialogues.text: Vamos a quitaros de aqui.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND TEXAN
dialogues.text: Yoaheah, Still the same plan.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: You and T-Bird take the wagon and we'll meet at Big Ed's in Acuna. The Mexican stoops beside Janet's body to pick up his goid butane lighter, Melio packs up the money and starts out the front door. T-Bird gestures toward Mark and Rane:

dialogues.speaker: T-BIRD
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: We'll have to stop them, of course, There's no stopping now. (looks at Rane) Yeah, Kill the poor son of a bitch.  326 T-Bird raises his revolver arm's length and shoots Mark in the head, Turning half-cirele, he aims his revolver and shoots Rane in the head. Charlie falls off the sofa and slumps to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MEXICAN
dialogues.text: (softly) Chupate esa. SCREEN GOES TO BLACK. cur TO:  336

dialogues.speaker: COMING TO
dialogues.text: SEVERAL DAYS LATER. The screen slowly comes into FOCUS. We see a NURSEâs face. The Nurse's eyes open with excitement. She calls out:

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Doctor! Doctor! Come quickly! He's coming to! There is the SOUND of FOOTSTEPS and the faces of two DOCTORS come into view. Behind them stands Col. Maxwell. One doctor bends toward us. CUT to third person POV. The doctors bend over Rane's bed. Col. Maxwell watches them. Charlie's head, face and left hand are heavily bandaged. His eyes are blurry, his face pale. Maxwell leans over to Charlie, putting his hand on the edge of the bed,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Charlie, can you hear me? Can you hear me? The doctor looks sharply at Maxwell but Maxwell's return glance indicates he feels he must continue.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Can you hear me, Charlie? This is very important. Can you tell us anything? Who were they? With great effort, Rane shakes his head "no" and sinks back to the pillow. The screen goes OUT OF FOCUS and slowly to BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: MEMORY FAILS
dialogues.text: FADE IN: several days later. Rane's HOSPITAL ROOM. Charlie's bed has been cranked up a bit and he has his eyes open, Around his bed stand Maxwell, an FBI INVESTIGATOR, and the Nurse. The walls of Charlie's large private room are lined with floral wreaths and bouquets. One bears the legend, "GET WELL SOON, LT, COL. RANE." Col, Maxwell bends toward Charlie while the Nurse looks admiringly one

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (reassuring) Youtre going to be all right, Charlie. The doctors say everything's going to be all right. Rane smiles weakly. A newspaper on Rane'ts bedstand proclaims: "RANE TO RECOV MAXWELL . I guess I should have known all along. Nothing could ever stop you. (pause) I hate to go through this again, but we have to. (gesturing) This is Special Investigator Tom Pesterhof from the FBI. He's here to help us. Festerhof draws near the bed:

dialogues.speaker: FESTERHOF
dialogues.text: If there's anything, anything at all, you might remember. No matter how insignificant. It might help us. It's been almost a week and the trail is getting colder every day. We have so little to go on. (a beat; no response) The entire combined forces of the United States Air Force, the FBI, the Texas Rangers, the Texas State Police and the Corpus Christi Police stand ready at your disposal. All we need is a little more information to swing into action.  35. Rane draws himself up in his bed a little:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Investigator, Like I told you and all those others, it's all a blank. I can't remember anything. Memory fails. The last thing I remember I was coming home from the clothes store, (a beat) Haventt the police been able to do anything?

dialogues.speaker: FESTERHOF
dialogues.text: We're doing everything we can. The Director has put top priority on this case, as has the President himself, We have instructions to apprehend these murderers at all costs, We've been instructed to add their names to the Ten Most Wanted list once we discover who they are,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Youtve got to keep trying to remember. Something has to come -back, -

dialogues.speaker: FESTERHOF
dialogues.text: Do you remember the hand? (holds up left hand)

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (growing impatient) No, I don't remember that either. I told you, it's all a blank, Maybe it was the head wound, I'm still dizzy most of the time. There's nothing therÃ©se. (gestures toward head) I was in the car, I walked toward the house, then I woke up here,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (reassuring) All right, Charlie, it's all right. (to Festerhof) Maybe you should go now. Festerhof excuses himself and exits.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (thin smile) So how are you, Bill?  36.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (returns smile) I'm fine, Charlie. is there anything I can do for you? Anything you would like to know?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Did you go to the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: How was it?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Small, quiet, dignified. The Secretary of Defense was there. Dr. Kissinger. General Westmoreland, Abrams. Westmoreland wants to come back out and visit you. The President sent a telegram. Did you read it? Maxwell reaches for telegram on bedstand.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Where were they buried? Does it look nice?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: It's very nice, Charlie. Two simple stones, It's in your family plot at Longworth.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You send them flowers, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Oh yes, Charlie,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Lots of flowers?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Fresh flowers every day.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (gesturing) Cause I don't need all these flowers here. You could send some of these over.  376

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Charlie. It's all been taken care of,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Good. SCREEN GOES TO BLACK. cur TO:  38.

dialogues.speaker: THIS TOO WILL PASS
dialogues.text: FADE IN: several days later. Charlie is sitting up in bed, His facial bandages have been removed (burn scars remain), and his head bandage is considerably smaller, On his lap rests a stack of old newspapers. Rane is going through them, reading press accounts of the murders and his recovery. The latest paper shows a picture of him sitting up in his bed smiling and waving. Cliff, wearing his policeman's uniform, walks into the room. Rane looks up,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Hey, Cliff,

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: How are you, Charlie? Cliff grasps Rane's good hand with both hands and shakes it firmly.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Great, Cliff, Getting better. Rane points to the newspaper photo:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: They're making me quite a star, Cliff is a little surprised by Charlie's "up" mood but doesn't say anything. For his part, Cliff is very "down," almost distraught. Cliff sees a steel artificial hand lying on the bedstand:

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I see they got you a new hand.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (picks it up) Yeah, Pretty snazzy, huh? It hurts a little to wear it at first, so I'm just sort of getting used to having it around. Charlie slips the artificial hand with its twin stain- less steel hooks onto his left hand to show Cliff how it will look.  396

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Youtll get the knack of it, all right. Rane puts the artificial hand back on the bedstand.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: I got some good news for you, Charlie. Some of the Corpus businessmen are getting together and want to partially reimburse you for your losses, you know, in the robbery.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No. No. Thank them, but tell them I don't want no more charity. Janet had some life insurance and I got that money coming and I can get along on that. I don't need anything else.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: (morbid) Well, if that's the way you want it. There is an awkward pause; finally Cliff lets out a deep sigh:

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: Oh, God, Charlie, life is lonely without her. Cliff swallows his tears:

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: She was some kind of woman, wasn't she, Charlie? I dontt know how im going to get along without ere Cliff brushes back his tears and sniffs, Charlie reaches out and puts his hand on Cliff's shoulder. Cliff sinks his head into Charlie's chest.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: (erying) We gotta get them bastards. We gotta get âtem. Oh, Janet. Rane comforts him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang together, Cliff. You'll be all right. It'll pass, It always passes, Life will go on. You will forget.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN GOES TO BLACK,
dialogues.text: cur TO: 40.

dialogues.speaker: THE VOICE OF EXPERIENCE
dialogues.text: FADE IN: Rane walks down the hospital corridor with Col. Maxwell, Rane is wearing hospital pajamas and a bathrobe -- and his new stainless steel hand, Several nurses watch adoringly as he passes,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: You all ready to go home, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Yep, I'm looking forward to getting out of here tomorrow,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: It may be kind of hectic.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I can handle it. Rane holds up his artificial hand, opens the claws:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Got a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: You're really getting good with that thing. Maxwell shakes out a cigarette and Charlie picks it up with his artificial hand, Rane places the cigarette in his mouth and Maxwell lights it for him.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Yep. Just like a regular hand, now. I can hold a newspaper, put on a shirt -- even tie my shoes,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: You've had plenty of time the last couple weeks to think things over. Has anything come back to you? Even the slightest detail? A color, a shape? The police are stymied, They need something to go on.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No, Bill, It's all gone for good. The dizziness went away but the memory never came back, I'll never remember anything. I think it's better that way.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe it is. (a beat) Honestly, Charlie, I think you can cope with these things better than I can.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Well, I've had plenty of experience. SCREEN GOES TO BLACK. cur TO:  43.

dialogues.speaker: A RASPING SOUND
dialogues.text: FADE IN: Late that night. It is about 2 a.m. in the dark hospital. The CAMERA slowly DOLLIES down the darkened corridor. In the distance we hear a RASPING SOUND: krerww, krerww. The silent TRACKING SHOT continues. We pass stationary hospital carts, closed doors, a night nurse silently working. The RASPING SOUND grows louder: Krerww, Krerww. We TRACK around a corner in the corridor and approach the partially open door to Ranets room, We track in. The RASPING SOUND is now louder. KRErww, KREerww. We TRACK across the room toward Rane's bed. A small night light shines about Charlie's bed, Rane is sitting up, working on something in his lap. We TRACK closer: KRERWW, KRERWW. The CAMERA CLOSES IN on Rane's work: he is slowly sharp- ening the hook of his artificial hand with a long metal file. With each long stroke, the claws become sharper. CUT TO his face: it is hard and determined. We suddenly realize Rane has never forgotten his night of torture. He knows what he must do.

dialogues.speaker: KRERWW
dialogues.text: cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: D DAY
dialogues.text: Approximately 8:30 a.m.: Charles Rane, neatly dressed in a conservative suit, walks briskly down the hospital cor- ridor with Col. Maxwell. There is considerable excitement up and down the corridors: Rane is being released. Several nurses and hospital personnel smile, wave or shak hands with the passing war hero. Charlie is also smiling, nodding goodbye. Approaching the front door, Rane and Maxwell brace them- selves. OUTSIDE: they are greeted by a cluster of pushing-shoving newsmen and photographers,

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (calling out) All right, men. You know the agreement. Only photographs. No questions. Rane poses for photographers and the cameras click away. After a moment, Maxwell thanks the newsmen and leads Rane to an awaiting Air Force car.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: (to photographers) Tomorrow, men, TIMECUT: Rane and Maxwell ride in the back seat of the AF car. A serviceman acts as chauffeur. Rane looks ahead with concern:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (to Maxwell) Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: I thought you'd want to stop at the cemetery a moment.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Well, not just yet. I want to come home and rest first. Just for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: You want me to stop over for a while?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No, I want to be alone. I'm sick of crowds. I'll see you again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MAXWELL
dialogues.text: Well, okay. (to driver) Go to Lt. Col. Rane's home. TIMECUT: The AF car pulls up in front of Rane's home and Charlie gets out. Maxwell gets out to follow Rane but Rane waves him off. The AF chauffeur also gets out but Rane waves him back also. Charlie walks toward the front door. Maxwell and the chauffeur look at each other, shrug, and get back into the car. Once inside the INT. LIVING ROOM, Rane peeks through the front curtain to see 1f Maxwell has left yet. After a moment, the AF car drives away. Rane turns and walks directly through the living room. The room has been straightened and cleaned; there is a new carpet, but Rane doesn't even pause long enough to notice. Entering his CELLAR/WORKSHOP, Rane walks directly to his gun rack. He starts pulling guns out of the rack and placing them on a work table. - It is an impressive collection: 2 nickel-plated Coit Commander .45 automatics, a Smith and Wesson 357 Combat Magnum, a snub-nosed Colt Cobra .22 revolver, a Wincheste 12 gauge Super 6~shot pump shotgun, 2 Browning B-SS 12 gauge Double Barrel shotguns, plus clips and boxes and boxes of ammunition. With his good hand, Rane clamps the Winchester 6-shot into his workbench vice and proceeds to saw off the barrel. The barrel CLANGS to the cement floor. CU: lying on the floor, the sawed-off barrel looks like the leavings of a major amputation. Rane starts carrying his guns into the LIVING ROOM. TIMECUT: soon they are all spread on the sofa. Going into his BEDROOM, Charlie removes his suit coat and shirt. He removes his freshly pressed blue AF uniform out of the closet on a hanger and places it on the bed. Rane removes the medals from the uniform and places them on the bed beside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIMECUT: Rane, wearing his uniform, finishes loading the last of his guns into the roomy trunk of the big red Cadillac. CU: the guns lie in neat rows on an old blanket. Rane removes a .45 and closes the trunk. Plac- ing the .45 under the front seat, he walks back toward the house. In the KITCHEN Rane rummages about for some food, but can only find a package of stale OREOs. He picks up the pack- age and a quart of J&B and walks back toward the living room. In the BEDROOM, he removes a stack of twenty dollar bills which had been hidden under the dresser, There appears to be about $500. When he slips the wad of bills into his pants pocket, Charlie feels something unusual there. Fishing around in his pocket, he comes out with a piece of paper. It reads: Linda Forchet TR6-3265 He looks at the paper a moment and walks back toward the living room. As he passes the bed, we notice the medals are no longer lying on it. By the time he gets in the LIVING ROOM, he has his mind made up. He sits down and dials the phone. He waits for the phone to ring. It does, and a girl's pleasant Texas VOICE comes on the other end.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Hello, JK Vending Machines.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Is this Linde Porchet?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Yes it is.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Well, hello, Linda. This is Charlie Rane. Remember me? We met at a press conference a couple weeks ago. You were...

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Wow! I remember. Of course I know who you are, Col. Rane,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: How are you?  AT.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (puzzled) I'm fine. How about you? I read about it in the papers. It was horrible...

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I'm great. It was nothing. The papers always play these things up. (a beat) Listen, Linda, I was thinking of taking a sort of little vacation and I wondered if you'd like to come?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.5S.)
dialogues.text: Where you going?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought Itd head over toward Acuna. Del Rio, that area. There's some nice country around there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There is?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Well, it ain't bad. No crowds. You wanna come?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Gee, I really can't, you know, Colonel? I got a job. What would my boss say? I just can't up and leave.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (persuasive) Ah, come on, Linda. You don't want to miss the chance of a lifetime, do you? We'll only be gone a couple~a days. Wetil have a great time. When will you get another opportunity like this?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I knew you'd love to come.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I didn't say I was gonna come.  4g,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Are you? (a beat) Aw, com'on, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Good, I'll pick you up in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: An hour?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Sure. Can you be ready?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't get off work until five.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Gee, I can't wait that long. Can't you get sick or something? I'ma nice guy, Linda. Honest, really I am.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm doing âthis.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No second thoughts, now.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll figure out a way. Don't know how, though. But you can't meet me here. And I have to go home and get some things. My hair needs to get done, too.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I'll take care of that. Where'll we meet?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: We can meet in the coffee shop on the corner by my apartment. That's the Eat-Rite coffee shop. The corner of 4th and Sam Houston. Right next to the Sav-More Drug Discount store.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: See you in an hour, Linda. cur TO:  49.

Rane's long red Caddy (top down) pulls up beside the EAT-RITE COFFEE SHOP. He HONKS the horn and waves inside. Linda Forchet comes bundling out, an overnight bag in her hand. She is wearing a short pleated purple skirt, a "grabeme" yellow pullover and mounds of enticingly coiffured blonde hair. Linda is everything Tammy Wynette sings about: ex cheerleader, ex-wife, 9-to-5 community chest. She's about 95% plastic, but the 5% that ain't gives her an edge on just about everybody else.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Hello, Lt. Colonel. Some car you got.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard, Linda. Rane's Cadillac works its way through the late morning traffic. Ever since his "accident," Charlie Rane's personality has taken a marked turn for the better. He seems more at ease, genial, confident. That uncertainty and unnamed fear are gone -~ or, perhaps, they have simply been driven underground, replaced by a deeper motivation which allows him to appear calm on the surface

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I pretended I got sick. I said I had cramps. Here, you know. (hold lower abdomen) Woman-type sick. That always works. There is no immediate response from Rane so Linda picks up the thin conversational thread again:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You don't give a person much time. (a beat) Where we going again?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Going to 'cuna, You ever been there?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That's a greaseball town, right? Over the line?  50.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Down from Del Rio.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: What's there?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Action. Some guys I used to know. The car radio has been playing softly, but Linda's ear catches a song she likes.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Oh, Tammy Wy-nette. Linda turns up the radio. Rane drives up the ramp to the expressway. Putting his hand on Linda's bare knee, he says:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Now watch this baby go. Charlie trounces on the accelerator: in a great arrogant purst of exhaust the huge red convertible fishtails down the highway. The radio plays as they speed west: âJust follow the stairway, To this lonely world of mine, You'll find me waiting here, In apartment number nine." cur TO:  51.

dialogues.speaker: MANLY ARROGANCE
dialogues.text: Somewhere west of Carrizo Springs, Rane pulls off Highway 83 and drives into an "EAT GAS" truckstop. A young Texan station attendant looks on with awe as Rane wheels the Caddy next to one of the pumps.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (getting out) Fillerup. Ethyl Supreme. Oil 'n water. Linda hops out and follows Charlie as he heads toward the restaurant. Her hair is pathetically windblown and she gropes for the hairbrush in her purse as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Jesus, Charlie, we was going so fast the words blown right outa my mouth. They catch the stares of several truckers as they enter the INT. TRUCKSTOP. Feeling their stares, Rane cups Linda's left ham in a display of manly arrogance. Em- barrassed, Linda removes his hand from her ass. Rane slides into a vinyl booth and Linda plops down across from him. They appear on very amiable terms. Rane slides the menu toward him but doesn't look at it. Linda vainly tries to brush her windblown hair:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Gee, I never thought you'd remember who I was.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't forget, Linda. Linda, a little embarrassed, tries to excuse herself for picking up Rane:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Golly, I'm just such a fool for Army men. Just show me anything in a uniform and I get all wet. (laughs at herself) I should be kept on a leash around Army bases.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You from Army people?  52.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was an Army brat. Dad was stationed at the Naval Air Station in Beeville. Then he got promoted and we moved to Corpus. He always said I shoulda stayed Army. He was real upset when I married Sam.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: âCause Sam was intellectual and all.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) No, why did you marry Sam?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Well, he just knew everything. He was real smart, not like me. I'm about as bright as a night- light. He'd made a gob of money in real estate and was handsome. The marriage wasn't his idea. I hit on him. But then he started getting into politics and dropped me like a hot potater. He's an aide to something or other now in Austin. I read his name once in the paper. Sometimes his mother calls -- she always liked me.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: That doesn't sound too bad to me.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn't so hot, I can tell you. Me about as sharp as a@ napkin and this guy always saying what is what. It was like that song, you know, "Satin sheets to lie on, satin pillows to cry on." That's Jeanne Pruit. Well I had them satin sheets up to here. (gestures) I mean Sam was important and all but he wasn't ever a real man. Never was. Just a talker. But I didn't do no worse than ny girlfriends. The ones that ain't unhappy jus' hang around the Naval Officers Club.  53.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Not like some people we know.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (shrugs } Well, you can meet some nice guys at the Officers Club. The waitress walks over:

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Ready to order, folks? Rane replies without ever taking his eyes off Linda. Linda smiles apologetically at the waitress.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Two cheeseburgs, fries and chocolate malts.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Make mine light on the ice cream, heavy on the mait. The waitress takes the order and leaves. Looking at the Jukebox selector in the booth, Linda searches for a coin in her purse. Rane pulls out a quarter and gives it to her.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Thanks. Linda puts the quarter into the box.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Damn. This is one of those new machines they got now. Only two plays for a quarter. That's a erime. I can't live without a jukebox. Linda pushes two selections and turns back to Charlie:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You see, I suffered, too, Charlie. Loretta Lynn's "Fist City" comes on the box.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I remember that song. It was around before I left. Loretta Lynn. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: She's a grandmother already.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No kiddin'? Wow. I heard Kitty Wells died. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Kitty Wells? Hell no. She's got her own TV show. Every Saturday morning. "The Kitty Wells Show." It's with her whole family.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Maybe it was somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Patsy Cline?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No, no. Patsy Cline died long before I even left. That was ages ago. Ina plane crash. I saw her perform once in San Anton. Maybe nobody died. Maybe I just got it all confused.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I don't know anybody who died. Do you know all the new singers?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Nah, not at all.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Who do you know?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Well, I remember the Queen, Kitty Welis, and Cute 'n Country Connie Smith, and Miss Tammy of course. I liked Bonnie Guitar a lot. And Dolly Parton -- she's nice.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear Susan Raye? She's real good.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: She's from California. Bakersfield. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LINDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's got a song that goes: (sings) "I guess my heart has a mind of its own."

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: But that's an old song. I heard it before.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: And then there's Jeanne Pruit, and, let's see, Barbara Fairchild, "The Teddy Bear Song." And little Tanya Tucker. She's only 14 years old. Donna Fargo. Conny VanDyk.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Wow, I never heard of any of them.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: We should stop and get a stereo and some albums. I'il help you pick 'em. You missed a lot. A young child about 8 walks by the booth and spots Charlie's shiny stainless steel hand. He stops and stares at it. His mother calls reprimandingly from a nearby booth:

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Billy! Rane replies to the mother:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: It's ali right, ma'am. The little boy connects Rane's uniform with his artificia hand:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Was you in the Army, mister?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (looking at hand) Did you get that in the Army?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Yep.  56.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow. That's neat. Kin I touch it?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Sure, Billy. BLily runs his hand up and down the glistening hook.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow. I wish I had one of those.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe when you grow up and go in the Army you can get one.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: You really think so? RANE . Sure. It happens all the time,

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Gee.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (from distance) Come back to the table, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: (looking back) I gotta go now,

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Here, I've got a present for you.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: What? Rane reaches in his back pocket and pulls out one of his medals. He hands it to Billy.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Wow! Kin I keep it?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Sure, it's yours. I've got plenty of them.

dialogues.speaker: , BILLY
dialogues.text: Gee, thanks. Billy walks away, admiring his new present.  57.

dialogues.speaker: RANE,
dialogues.text: âBye, Billy. Billy walks off. Rane looks back at Linda, Tears are coming down her cheeks. He holds her hand:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Oh, baby. Come on. Pull yourself together. Your malt's coming. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big red Cad hauls ass down U.S. 277. 100 mph, maybe more, The SOUNDTRACK plays on: "You better move your feet, If you don't want to eat, A meal that's called Fist City." TIMECUT: Rane and Linda pull into the Del Rio city limits. Population 10,000. Crossing through the town, they drive south toward the border, Rane pulis off the read and drives into the lot of the NO-TELL MOTEL. It is about 4:00 p.m. Linda, straightening her hair -- now a hopeless task, watches Charlie as he checks in, comes out with a key and walks into a nearby room. Linda picks up her overnight bag and follows. INSIDE the MOTEL ROOM Rane walks into the bathroom and washes his face and hands. Linda sets her bag down and flops onto the bed. The walls of the room are pink, the tufted bedspread purple, and a print of a bullfighter decorates one wall. Linda watches Charlie soulfully. "Her man" strips to the waist, and washes his sinewy trunk with a damp washcloth and redresses. Linda pulls up her thin yellow ribbed pullover just below her breasts, revealing a deliciously tanned band of skin. Kicking off her shoes, she sensuously sets her heels against the purple bedspread. Leaving the bathroom in a mess, Charlie walks back into the room and eyes Linda. Rane hack-coughs: he is not well. Seeing the messy bathroom, Linda says playfully:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Don't you ever clean up behind yourself?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: That's why God made Mexicans. Smiling apologetically, Rane turns and walks toward the door: he has priorities higher than sex.  59. Rane opens the door and walks outside. Linda, shocked, jumps up and runs after him, OUTSIDE, she finds him resting against the Caddy waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Hey, whatcha doing? Don't you want me to come along?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Of course I do. I was just waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Into Acuna. Boys Town.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (shocked ) Boys Town! God! What are you going to do there?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: There are some men I need to find.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I doing here?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I want you to help me.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Help you?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Some of these men may recognize me. I need someone they don't know.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Don't know? Who are these men?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: They're the men that hurt me, Linda.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (catching on) My God! Oh no. Not this. You just brought me along as a decoy, didn't you? You justâ want to usÃ© me. Oh no,â I'm about as slow as a Chinese funeral, I never catch on.  60.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: I want you to help me. This is something you should do.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: God, why do I always end up with the crazy men?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: That's âcause there's a shortage of the other kind. You have to take what you can get.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Not me.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (sincere) Linda, I need your help. You can help me,

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, like bait in a trap.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: There are worse things. (pause) Linda, this means little to you, but it means everything to me. (a beat) Will you come?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Well, I ain't got much choice, do I? cur TO:  61.

dialogues.speaker: THE INSIDE MAN
dialogues.text: Charlie and Linda pass through Customs, pay the 20Â¢ toll and cross the border into Acuna. They pass through the business district of Acuna -- a pretty sorry-~looking place -- and head south. The peasants look up in wonder as the giant car passes. They pass through the "proper" business district of Acuna and reach a large, vacant, weed-infested, bottle- strewn field. Rane thumpety~thumps the Cadillac across the field. The field is kept unkempt to separate the town proper from the Boys Town Â«â and with good reason. The Acuna Boys Town (because that's where the "boys" go) is about the seediest of all the seedy border towns stretching from Tijuana to Neuvo Laredo. Most of the other border towns halted their forward progress in about 1935; Acuna, however, is suspended in 1890. Rows of tacky bars and brothels are banked up from the gutted one-lane white dust streets. There are few electric lights and horses and carriages amble down the narrow street. The bars have names like "El Lobo," "El Coyote," "El Caballo." Rane drives his big convertible down the middle of the narrow street, forcing the horses and carriages to the side as he goes. It is an arrogant breach of convention. Border lowlife look down at Rane and Linda from the high curb embankments. Rane finds an opening between two buildings and pulls the car into it. He cuts the engine. Looking down the row of seedy bars, his eyes light on a painted sign reading "La Mujer Negro." He motions to it:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: That's a good starting place. Go over there. Ask for a guy named Big Ed. Say you've been sent to see him.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Whatja mean, go in there? That's greaseballville in there. No decent person would go in there.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Nothing can happen to you. It's broad daylight.  62.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I was willing to do something for you, Charlie, but not this. Let's go back. This is painful. Humiliating. Rane starts to run out of patience. There's no way, of course, he's going to go back. Instead of getting angry at Linda, however, he speaks with passion.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Linda, I'1l1 make this short but it's important. There is something you have to understand. These things are not important. Honest. All these external things like pain, humiliation, sorrow, pleasure, fame, happiness, love, sex, glory, emotions, they are nice, but they are not important. You can live without them. They exist on the outside; they are not real. The only thing real 1s the inside, the interior life, and that has nothing to do with the outside. The life that comes from within... here... (holds heart) +eÂ» and here... (holds head) Â«+. these are the real things. That is where you live. Nothing else matters. I'm telling you the truth now. You may have not heard it before but it's the truth nonetheless. Once you live inside those things don't matter. (a beat) Honest, Linda, believe me. It 1s a deranged speech -- but persuasive. Linda is nearly mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You're crazy, Charlie. As crazy as a jaybird in the snow.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Will you go? (a beat) For me?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I don't suppose anything can happen. Poor Linda. Here she goes again,  63.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: WL1L you?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yes. For you, Charlie, for you. She embraces him and they kiss. She is still embracing him as he reaches under the seat and pulls out his nickel-plated .45 automatic. He slips it into his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: All right, let's go. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: TIO TACO
dialogues.text: Thrusting all her WASP sexuality before her, Linda struts into the dingy bar. The snuff queen comes home. Every eye turns to greet her. There are several exclam- ations of "Vaya Mujer" ("What a woman!"), A young unattractive half-naked white girl is dancing to the Spanish R&B jukebox. A couple lackadaisical Mexican hookers work the bar. Linda walks up to the FIRST BARTENDER:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Big Ed. I was sent here for him. Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: 1ST BARTENDER
dialogues.text: No entiendo, No Ingles. Que se yo? A SECOND BARTENDER walks up:

dialogues.speaker: 2ND BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Big Ed? Don't know nobody by that name. (calling out) Hay alguien que sabe "Big Eda"? No one answers. Finally a DRUNKEN MEXICAN calls out:

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Big Ed?

dialogues.speaker: 2ND BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Si. Big Ed.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: I know Blg Ed. Big Ed's a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: 2ND BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Well, this lady is a friend of his. The Drunken Mexican walks over to Linda.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: I know Big Ed. Follow me. He gestures for her to follow him to the back of the bar. She does.

As they pass he sees a little local Acuna color: three drunken Mexicans sit in a booth with an old car battery on the table. They take turns holding the live wires attached to the battery, each seeing who can hold on the longest. Each effort calls for more laughs and more beers. The Drunken Mexican leads Linda into a small PRIVATE ROOM at the rear of the bar. It's pretty clear by now that our Mexican friend isn't going to tell Linda about Big Ed until she provides him with certain obvious favors ~- and even then it's doubtful. Linda seems uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Why do you want to see Big Ed? He's my friend.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I'm gonna be his girl. I was sent here.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Good. Big Ed likes beautiful gringo girls. cuT: Charles Rane strolls into the INT. BAR looking for Linda. Unable to find her, he seems upset. His arti~ ficial hand is artfully tucked into his pants pocket. He walks to the rear of the bar where he overhears the voices of Linda and the Drunken Mexican. cUT: INT. PRIVATE ROOM

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: (cocky) I'm Big Ed's friend. He likes people who do things for me, (a beat) Do something for me and I will tell you where to find him.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (uneasy) What?

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: You know, this. (points to crotch)

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Big Ed wouldn't like that.  66.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Oh si, he would very much. (a beat) Besides you have no choice, puta.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I can leave.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: You will not leave, bitch. The Mexican puts his hand up to Linda's cheek. The door opens: Charles Rane, tall in his sky-blue AF uniform, walks in. The Mexican looks at his partially hidden hook:

dialogues.speaker: . DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: You look like you could use a hand, gringo. (laughs)

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: (to Linda) You did real fine, Linda. Now wait for me in the car.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: She goes nowhere, Yankee.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Go on, Linda. You did real good. Linda gets up and Charlie takes her seat. The Drunken Mexican gets up to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: No se para. The above is a Latin American pun meaning both "Don't stand up" and "Don't get an erection." The Mexican chuckles and sits down. Rane sits down and puts on a phony polite smile:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Now, spic, you're going to tell me where Big Ed is.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: I tell you nothing, maricon.  67.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You tell now.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Screw. The Drunken Mexican gets up from his chair, dragging his right hand across the table as he goes. Rane suddenly whips his sharpened left hook from under neath the table and sinks it into the back of the Mex- dean's right hand, locking it to the table top. The Mexican YELPS. With his right hand, Charlie pulls the .45 from his waist and alms it point blank at the Mexican's face:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Now, tio taco, you're going to tell me where Big Ed is or I'm going to spread your brains against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: I don't know no Big Ed. Standing up, Rane presses the .45 against the Mexican's forehead, forcing him to his knees.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Don't mess with me, taco-face. I could make a stone talk.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: (crying) Don't know. Don't know.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Talk or die. Rane prepares to pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: DRUNKEN MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Go to the El Lobo. They know where he is. Ask Billy Sanchez, the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Good. Rane removes the hook from the Mexican's hand and tucks his .45 back into his shirt.  68. The Mexican, holding his bloody hand, runs from the room. . Charlie wipes his bloody hook against his blue pants and prepares to exit. Walking back into the INT. BARROOM, Rane sees the patrons, bartender and stripper, staring at him in Silence. Looking at the doorway he sees several Mexican toughs waiting for him. Using his hook hand, he pulls open his shirt to reveal his shiny .45. There is a pause, and the group breaks up. Rane strides through the bar and out the door,

dialogues.speaker: JUST THE PRELIMINARY STUFF
dialogues.text: Night is falling as Rane and Linda walk down the street toward the El Lobo. The streets, having no electrical lighting, are dark and foreboding. As they approach the El Lobo Linda says:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Let me take care of this one my way.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Okay with me. The entrance to the El Lobo, a classy (?) private club-brothel, can be seen at the end of a narrow alley. Rane pauses a moment, letting Linda walk ahead of him. Several Mexicans check the guests as they enter the El Lobo. Linda simply struts through them. Again: vaya mujer. INSIDE, Linda walks up to the bar and sits down. The El Lobo is several notches up from the La Mujer Negro -- or down, depending on your viewpoint. On stage two naked teenage girls, one white and one black, close dance with each other in front of a red-neon-lighted Spanish band. And this is only the early show. The bar is dripping with hooker, gangster and Texas macho types. Linda's up front sexuality fits right in. Linda calls the bartender over:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Is Billy Sanchez here?

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Ahorita. The Bartender walks off and comes back with Billy Sanchez, an American.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Yeah, baby?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Big Ed.  70.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Youtre a real nice piece of something, honey babe.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: I'm Big Ed's new gal. I met him up in Corpus. He told me to meet him here.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Ah, Eddie gets it all, you know? Why can't I get some, honey? Charlie Rane walks into the El Lobo, surveying the scene. His eyes stop as they catch the dancing teenage couple.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: You look pretty good to me, Billy S., but I'm already a day late for Big Ed and if he don't find me quick he's gonna get angry. Rane walks over to the bar and sits several patrons away from Linda.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Well, he ain't even here. âThey all went to El- Paso.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Yeah, the whole bunch.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Was T-Bird with them?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: T-Bird?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. He drives a Ford wagon.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Ah, Jimmy the T-Bird Jones, the Texaskan. Yeah, he's with 'em. They all went to Paso to celebrate. They made a big score.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Where are they?  Tl.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: They'd be at the John Wayne house. Big Duke used to live there.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Where's that?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Hmm. On Peacock. Off Arroyo. A couple houses south.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Thanks, Billy. Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Why don't you stay and see the show? It gets pretty good later. This is just the preliminary stuff. Maybe there'd be something you'd like here better than El Paso. Drinks on me.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (smiling) Could be, Rane seems a little upset: his disciple has learned her lesson too well. He walks over-to Linda and Billy. He threateningly raises his sharpened hook to Billy's face and says:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: El cigarillo? Sanchez replies:

dialogues.speaker: BILLY SANCHEZ
dialogues.text: Sure. And gives him a cigarette. Rane picks it up with his hook and Billy lights it for him. All three turn and watch the show for a moment. A FAT NAKED MEXICAN man has stepped on stage and the two naked teenage girls are bending down, kissing his feet, work= ing up. Microphone in hand, the Fat Mexican sings as he is being mock+seduced. His singing is sort of a south-of~the~-border parody of Screaming Jay Hawkins: all yelps and chants.

dialogues.speaker: FAT MEXICAN
dialogues.text: Yow, ah. Get it, get it, get. Cupe, cupe, cupe. Eee-oww! The patrons cheer. Rane watches closely.  Te. TIMECUT: It is about 8:30. All is dark in the streets of Acuna Boys Town. Rane and Linda get into the Cadillac. Rane starts the engine, turns on the lights and pulls into the narrow street. Proceeding slowly down the dark street, Rane sees some figures in the distance. There is the glint of a gun. We see the partially-lit face of the Drunken Mexican. Rane says to Linda:

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Get down. Linda crouches behind the dashboard. Charlie raises the .45, fires two shots into the air and trounces on the accelerator. Spitting white dust, the giant car charges forward. A few shots harmlessly discharge at the Cadillac as it speeds through the street. curt To:  73.

dialogues.speaker: A PACK OF OREOS, A QUART OF SCOTCH AND THOU
dialogues.text: Rane and Linda pull into the motel gravel lot. Rane gets out of the car and walks into the motel room. Linda, exhausted, follows. _ INSIDE the MOTEL ROOM, Linda drops her tired body into an easy chair. Charlie steps into the bathroom, splashes some cold water on his face and walks back into the bed- room. He picks up Linda's overnight bag and proceeds toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (astonished) Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: El Paso.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: That's 450 miles! I'm pooped.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: You can sleep in the car.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: In the car -~ at 110 miles per hour?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: Just crawl in the back seat. I'll put the top up.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: (ironic) The grand concession. (a beat) What about food? I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: There's food in the car. Linda stands up:

dialogues.speaker: LINDA
dialogues.text: Sheeit. Don't you ever sleep in a bed?

dialogues.speaker: RANE
dialogues.text: We'll sleep when it's all over.  74. TIMECUT: Rane's Cadillac (top up) cruises at high speed through the night down Highway 90. A C&W station plays softly on the radio. INT. CAR: Linda is all huddled up in a corner of the back seat. The half-opened pack of OREOs rests in her lap. She listlessly pulls out an OREO, twists it in half, examines each half and munches on one of them. Charlie sits at the wheel, tugging at the quart of J&B as he drives. TIMECUT: Later that night, about 2 a.m. Linda is asleep in the back seat. Charlie takes another drink of J&B. The bottle is half- empty. Feeling sleepy, he turns up the CAR RADIO. The vast desert countryside stretches into miles and miles of dark nothingness. Two lonely headlights flash through the night. The radio plays Jeanne Pruit: "Satin sheets to lie on, Satin pillows to cry on, Still I'm not happy don't you see, Big long Cadillac, Tailor-mades upon my back, Still I want you to set - me free," Rane mumbles along with the song: "Big long Cadillac... I want you to set me free." The song FADES OUT but Rane keeps mumbling to himself, as if he wants to say something but can't verbalize it. There is a sudden explosion +- BLOWOUT! -- and the Cadillac CAREENS madly to the right. Rane struggles frantically to maintain control of the runaway car as it charges into the desert night. Linda, bouncing about in the back seat, SCREAMS. In the middle of this nightmare ride the car RADIO starts up with a hillbilly song. The Caddy bounces across several low gullies and ridges and Linda is tossed over the front seat into the dash- board. The open bottle of J&B smashes against the dashboard beside her.  75. The Cadillac finally thumps to a rest hundreds of yards from the highway. The radio BLARES,. Charlie turns down the incongruous radio and then, re= laxing his arms, gives out a deep sigh. He is shaking with fear and exhilaration. Linda, her face livid in the moonlight, trembles out of control. She tries to speak but can only stammer and cry. WEEPING, she falls on Charlie's shoulders.
